independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

To strengthen the necessary policy, legislative and financial instruments as well as the capacity of government and civil society stakeholders in partnership with the oil and gas industry to protect and conserve marine and coastal biodiversity.

comment.narrative: There are no significant changes attributable to poor management of oil and gas developments
There are no significant changes attributable to poor management of oil and gas developments.

description.narrative: 2. Degree to which policies and regulations governing the development of the oil and gas sector include measures to conserve and safeguard marine and coastal biodiversity within the EEZ

comment.narrative: Biodiversity is not mainstreamed in policies and regulations governing the development of the oil as analyzed during the PPG. A thorough policy screening will define the baseline more precisely.
At least half of the policies and regulations considered relevant for governing the development of the oil effectively

Three missions were carried out to monitor the quality of Mauritanian marine environment. Both analyses of micro-contaminants (PHAs, PCBs, trace metals) and detection of indirect clues of their presence (toxicity test with bioassays and exposure evaluation with biomarkers were carried out). The objective of these missions is to define the baseline of micro-contaminants to trigger early warning and develop norms for the oil and gas companies. On the other hand, the project is about to select an international bureau to develop basic norms in order to help the Ministry of Environment to strengthen its monitoring procedures to make it more operational and in accordance to the regulations. On the other hand, two activities are ongoing. The first one is regarding the development of a joint decree from the Ministries (Environment, Health and Industry) on industry waste disposal, hygiene and health. A joint order from three Ministries (Environment, Oil and Fishery) is being established on Environmental Impact Assessments (EIA) in order to develop a specific Environmental Management Plan to oil activities.

description.narrative: 3. Improved results from the GEF SO2 Tracking Tool and increased scores UNDP Capacity Development Scorecard

comment.narrative:
Financial Scorecard:
1) Legal, reg. & inst. frameworks [19%]
2) BP & tools for cost-effective PA mgt [26%]
3) Tools for revenue generation [18%]
General Avg. [21%]
Cap. Dev. Scorecard:
Systemic [32%]
Institutional [43%]
Individual [44%]
General Avg. [41%]
Scores, expressed in absolute terms, increase by at least 10%
Both tracking tools have been completed for the MTE in 2013, and again for the TE expected to be carried out by November 2015.

description.narrative: Marine and coastal biodiversity conservation mainstreamed into the governance frameworks for the oil and gas sector and into the industryÃ¢â¬â¢s operations
4. Un atlas de vulnÃÂ©rabilitÃÂ© ÃÂ©cologique et socio-ÃÂ©conomique de la ZEE est ÃÂ©tabli

comment.narrative: No ecologically sensitive \\\\\\\'no-go zones\\\\\\\' have been established
There is generalized compliance with Ecologically sensitive \\\\\\\'no-go zones\\\\\\\'

The project is carrying out the development of a Strategy and an Action Plan of the Abidjan's Convention for Cooperation in the Protection, Management and Development of the Marine and Coastal Environment of the Atlantic Coast of the West, Central and Southern Africa Region. The Atlas on the vulnerability of the Marine and Coastal Ecosystem have been translated in English and Arabic in order to sensitize all stakeholders on the need to protect the marine and coastal biodiversity.

description.narrative: 5. The oil and gas industry in Mauritania adopts a set of biodiversity standards for their operations; standards whose implementation can be independently verified

comment.narrative: No clear biodiversity standards yet adopted by industry
At least two key off-shore industry players adopt biodiversity standards as a result of industry engagement efforts by the project
An International Bureau is being engaged to develop (by November 2015) specific norms and catalogue for Oil and Gas industry in Mauritania.

description.narrative: Financial flows to promote biodiversity conservation are strengthened through partnerships between the public sector and the oil and gas secto

6. A well capitalized and operational Ã¢â¬Ëconservation finance mechanismÃ¢â¬â¢
Quantitative measures will be defined once agreement can be reached on the options and the goals of the mechanism.

comment.narrative: Options for the mechanism have been defined but no decision made

The Ã¢â¬Ëconservation finance mechanismÃ¢â¬â¢ is established and operational; it counts on an appropriate governance board and sufficient finance to fulfill its goal; it has an initial batch of relevant projects/initiatives approved

Kosmos Energy has committed up to 90,000 Euros to fund one mission in sea to assess bird and cetacean populations. The National Environmental Committee pledged up to 260,000 Euros to fund the monitoring of the quality of Mauritanian marine environment in 2015 and analyze the remaining samples taken from previous missions in 2012, 2013 and 2014.
Discussions are being held with the BaCOMaB fund (a judiciary fund for marine protected areas established in Mauritania) in order to build partnerships with the project.

description.narrative: Capacity of key stakeholders in public sector and civil society is strengthened for monitoring marine and coastal biodiversity and environmentally sound decision-making related to the development of the oil and gas sector
7. Increase in awareness levels among relevant stakeholders, as assessed through the independent application of the methodology Most Significant Change

comment.narrative:
Not Applicable
The MSC technique is to be applied once the project has been launched and some form of change has occurred. The baseline corresponds to all assessments that corroborate the situation analysis for this project, particularly with respect to land-uses and livelihoods.
Changes in awareness levels are assessed through the independent application of the MSC technique

The project launched last year a Master on the Management of the Impacts of the Extractive Companies. The second class is made of 16 students from Mauritania, Senegal, Mali and Burkina Faso. The project held a two-days workshop to sensitize the environment network of members of parliament and mayors on the protection of marine and coastal biodiversity and the potential impacts of oil exploration and exploitation on the biodiversity. On the other hand, around 40 NGOs were trained on the same topics. The project supported various ministries and NGOs with provision of materials and equipment to monitor the marine water quality. The project assisted ONISPA (Office National d'Inspection Sanitaire des Produits de PÃªche et de l'Aquaculture) to operationalize its biomarker Unit and train its staff to the use of Gas Chromatography.
Finally, leaflets, posters and brochures were developed and shared with stakeholders (NGOs, government institutions) to raise their awareness on the need to conciliate oil production with the protection of marine and coastal biodiversity.
